sentence1: Long, long ago there lived a widow who had three sons.
sentence2: The two eldest were grown up, and though they were known to be idle fellows, some of the neighbours had given them work to do on account of the respect in which their mother was held.

sentence2: Then Pinkel hastily poured all the contents of the bowl into his bag, and make a great noise with his spoon, as if he was scraping up the last morsel.

sentence1: Then Pinkel hastily poured all the contents of the bowl into his bag, and make a great noise with his spoon, as if he was scraping up the last morsel.
sentence2: do give me some more,' said Pinkel, turning towards her.

sentence1: do give me some more,' said Pinkel, turning towards her.
sentence2: 'Well, you have a fine appetite, young man,' answered the witch;

sentence1: 'Well, you have a fine appetite, young man,' answered the witch;
sentence2: 'however, it is the last time you will ever eat it, so I will give you another bowlful.'

sentence1: 'however, it is the last time you will ever eat it, so I will give you another bowlful.'
sentence2: And rubbing in the poisonous herbs, she poured him out half of what remained, and then went to the window to call her cat.

sentence1: And rubbing in the poisonous herbs, she poured him out half of what remained, and then went to the window to call her cat.
sentence2: In an instant Pinkel again emptied the porridge into the bag, and the next minute he rolled on the floor, twisting himself about as if in agony, uttering loud groans the while.

sentence1: In an instant Pinkel again emptied the porridge into the bag, and the next minute he rolled on the floor, twisting himself about as if in agony, uttering loud groans the while.
sentence2: Suddenly he grew silent and lay still.

sentence1: Suddenly he grew silent and lay still.
sentence2: I thought a second dose of that poison would be too much for you,' said the witch looking at him.

sentence1: I thought a second dose of that poison would be too much for you,' said the witch looking at him.
sentence2: 'I warned you what would happen if you came back.

sentence1: 'I warned you what would happen if you came back.
sentence2: I wish that all thieves were as dead as you!

sentence1: I wish that all thieves were as dead as you!
sentence2: But why does not my lazy girl bring the wood I sent her for, it will soon be too dark for her to find her way?

sentence1: But why does not my lazy girl bring the wood I sent her for, it will soon be too dark for her to find her way?
sentence2: I suppose I must go and search for her.

sentence1: I suppose I must go and search for her.
sentence2: And she went to the door to watch if there were any signs of her daughter.

sentence1: And she went to the door to watch if there were any signs of her daughter.
sentence2: 'It is no night for my cloak,' she muttered;

sentence1: 'It is no night for my cloak,' she muttered;
sentence2: So she took it off her shoulders and hung it carefully up in a cupboard in the room.

sentence1: So she took it off her shoulders and hung it carefully up in a cupboard in the room.
sentence2: After that she put on her clogs and started to seek her daughter.

sentence1: After that she put on her clogs and started to seek her daughter.
sentence2: The witch, who was just entering the forest, turned round at that moment and saw the golden rays.

sentence1: The witch, who was just entering the forest, turned round at that moment and saw the golden rays.
sentence2: She forgot all about her daughter, and ran down to the shore, screaming with rage at being outwitted a third time.

sentence1: She forgot all about her daughter, and ran down to the shore, screaming with rage at being outwitted a third time.
sentence2: 'Have you taken my gold cloak?'

sentence1: 'Have you taken my gold cloak?'
sentence2: But, all the same, he carried the cloak to the king's palace, and in return he received the hand of the king's daughter in marriage.

sentence1: But, all the same, he carried the cloak to the king's palace, and in return he received the hand of the king's daughter in marriage.
sentence2: People said that it was the bride who ought to have worn the cloak at her wedding feast;

sentence2: but the king was so pleased with it that he would not part from it;

sentence2: and let up hope that he gave up his bad and thievish ways, and ruled his subjects well.

sentence1: and let up hope that he gave up his bad and thievish ways, and ruled his subjects well.
sentence2: As for his brothers, he did not punish them, but left them in the stables, where they grumbled all day long.
